title: What will the UK Office of National Statistics report the UK unemployment rate to be for the period March-May 2020?
preds: as this is a rolling average with the fulough scheme in place for a couple months now, May unemployment is likely to be lower increase than April. 2m drawing benefit in April implies c6%. i think to get above 7% requires a huge increase in May.

UK unemployment seems to be calculated in a 3 month moving average. March was 3.9%. It is well reported April was up 69%, which would be 6.59% for April. May is projected to be 8-10%, which would put the three month average between the 6-7% range. May would have to be above 10.45% for the average to go above 7%, which I find unlikely because it makes more sense for most of the unemployment claims to be in the first month of the lockdown. The lockdown started the last week of March. In the US initial jobless claims peaked the second week of the lockdown and dropped every week after that. So it is unlikely the UK May jump will be more than the UK April jump. I am giving the above 7% category a little extra credit because I don't want to underestimate the impact of the virus and because I thought we were heading into a global recession before the virus even hit. https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/may/07/uk-economy-to-shrink-by-25-percent-and-unemployment-to-double-warns-bank-of-england-coronavirus
https://www.focus-economics.com/country-indicator/united-kingdom/unemployment
A day to go and I'll go all in.

"Ministers have told the Financial Times that Mr Sunak and prime minister Boris Johnson are planning a big stimulus package, expected to be announced before the summer, amid warnings that Britain’s jobless rate may soon hit 10 per cent of the workforce." https://www.ft.com/content/425f4baa-ab57-44a5-93ee-8a90a856789e
Bank of England talking about potential doubling of unemployment rate in second quarter.

Last adjustment, before the question ends. So many uncertainties, especially about the way they will count the cases and how fast they will be.
So this is my best guess with the little really reliable data we have: expected corridor: 6% +/- 1.
To stay below 5, numbers for April and May would need to be much lower than any expert in the field expects, so i´m ruling that out. To get over seven we would need it to be their worst-case-scenario for both months. Although I don´t expect that to happen in the UK: still 18% for COVID-19 rule number one: with COVID it gets worse than expected - whatever you expected.
Hedging my estimate towards the crowd to reflect that I might not be understanding the question correctly.

"Economists at Goldman Sachs ... expect the unemployment rate to rise from a pre-virus low of 3.8 per cent to a peak of 8.5 per cent in the second quarter, the largest increase over three months since the 1930s Depression." https://www.ft.com/content/d14887e2-a52a-40a4-8deb-28828c764141

Hedging my bets downward after reading up on how this is calculated. Thanks to helpful comments from @sebawi and @Vidur_Kapur. Average of 3.9, 5.8-6.0 and 8-10. => 5.9-6.6%. I'm expanding my error bar further to 5.7 - 6.8%  to reflect the uncertainties around how the number will be calculated, since the UK govt may be tempted to tweak methodology interpretations to political ends in the crisis.

circa 2.1m claiming unemployment benefit end April which suggests 6.23%. that is likely to climb in May but need to take account of seasonal adjustments. i think on balance it will stay under 7% but its close.

The May report has been released [1], reporting unemployment from Jan-Mar, which decreased to 3.9% from the previous period (Dec-Feb) of 4.0%. Note that the most data for this survey was collected prior to the lockdown. It's also important to read section 3 about how anyone who works at least one hour or is expecting to return to a job (includes furloughed workers) do not count as unemployed: "The International Labour Organization (ILO) definition of employment includes those who worked in a job for at least one hour and those temporarily absent from a job. Workers furloughed under the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme or who are self-employed but temporarily not in work have a reasonable expectation of returning to their jobs after a temporary period of absence. Therefore they are classified as employed under the ILO definition." It's also very important to note that given the question will resolve based on Mar-Jun, it will include in its average the March numbers, which we know from the recently published Single-Month unemployment rate estimate for March [2] was 3.7%. So, as an example, even if real unemployment in the single month of April jumps to 7% and May jumps to 10%, the unemployment average over that period would still be below the highest bin, at 6.9%. HOWEVER, a Berenberg analyst suggests a rise to 9.5% in late second quarter from the 3.9% for the period ending in March [3]. I read that 9.5% number to mean the June numbers to be published in the Apr-Jun report, since 3.9% is the same as the Jan-Mar report released today. Assuming the growth is linear between the period ending in March and the period ending in Jun, that would mean the reports would look something like this: Jan-Mar | 3.9%
Feb-Apr | 5.8%
Mar-May | 7.6%
Apr-Jun | 9.5% In this case, the correct answer for this question would be 7.6%, which puts us in the highest bin. That would be pretty alarming - it would suggest that even when averaged with March's ~3.7% single-month rate, April and May's single month numbers would have to be an average of ~10%, so perhaps 8% and 12% or something like that. If, however, the analyst is talking about single-month metrics, then maybe the figures above would instead be  Mar | 3.9%
Apr | 5.8%
May | 7.6%
Jun | 9.5% in which case the average for Mar-May would be 5.8%. I'm going to lean toward the former, interpreting the analyst as speaking about the Jun report suggesting that the rate will be closer to 7.6% in the Mar-May report. We should be able to narrow it down once we get the Feb-Apr numbers on June 16th. I'm revising my forecast upward, but still leaving some in the middle and mid-to-high bin. Pre-mortem:
* Too much faith in a single analyst (for example, maybe they're not accounting for furloughed workings being counted as employed; seems unlikely though)
* Misinterpretation of single month vs three-month average Thanks to @sebawi and @Vidur_Kapur for below comments inspiring approach and sources here. [1] https://www.ons.gov.uk/employmentandlabourmarket/peopleinwork/employmentandemployeetypes/bulletins/employmentintheuk/may2020
[2] https://www.ons.gov.uk/employmentandlabourmarket/peopleinwork/employmentandemployeetypes/articles/singlemonthlabourforcesurveyestimates/may2020
[3] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/19/uk-jobless-claims-rise-by-70percent-in-april-to-2point1-million.html

If the following assumptions are true, then there will probably be an unemployment rate of ~6.0% [1]: - unemployment rate for ...
* March: ~3.9%
* April: ~5.8%
* May estimate by Berenberg is correct: 9.5% - three-month unemployment rate is calculated by taking the average of the unemployment rate of each month Notably, the error margin for the unemployment rate is around 3% [2]. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1036698
[2] https://www.bbc.com/news/business-22870886

Based on my initial take on the relation between unemployment numbers and unemplyoment rate, the unemplyoment rate should be well above 7.0% [1]. Currently, there are more than 3.3 million people officially registered as unemployed meaning they are also not covered by the furlough scheme [2,3,4]. Assuming we have ~34 million as the base of people able to work, then we would only need to have ~2.38 million unemployed people to get above 7.0%. In reference to official statistics, Berenberg indicates that the unemployment rate was ~3.9% in March, ~6.0% in April and expects it to be ~9.5% for May [4].  That said, I'm still conflicted about the probabilities here. I've just realized I I'm lacking crucial knowledge about the way the three-month unemployment rate will be estimated eventually. Do they take averages? If so, the average of the three months will be close to 7.0% but not above 7.0%. Or do they only count the totals of those unemployed at the end of May? Then the rate is in fact above 7.0%. Maybe someone can enlighten me?  [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1003758
[2] https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/may/17/britain-is-at-risk-of-returning-to-80s-levels-of-unemployment
[3] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/19/uk-jobless-claims-rise-by-70percent-in-april-to-2point1-million.html
[4] https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2020/05/19/jobs-market-shows-first-damaging-effects-coronavirus/

Mostly going off @Ewell_Gregoor excellent contributions, though a bit more towards middle end as even a jump of 2% would be much higher than historical precedent according to ONS data - though not impossible in these times.  https://www.ons.gov.uk/employmentandlabourmarket/peoplenotinwork/unemployment/timeseries/mgsx/lms (Plus extension of furlough scheme may make May rate a little lower than previously predicted by BoE etc).
Hedging upward for a week or two until the next report comes out.

Previously at 4%, highest historically at 12%: https://tradingeconomics.com/united-kingdom/unemployment-rate https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/apr/21/uk-furlough-scheme-unemployment-rise-coronavirus BoE presumes 8%: https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/may/07/uk-economy-to-shrink-by-25-percent-and-unemployment-to-double-warns-bank-of-england-coronavirus Finally, a prediction of 10% in Q2: https://www.statista.com/statistics/1107870/uk-unemployment-forecast/ All told 8-10% with a potential drag of the furlough numbers. I'm ready to be a little more confident in my assumption. (i.e. I'll die on this hill if need be. With the US at ~14% I'd be shocked to see the UK with a furlough offset of ~7%... someone comment/correct me if I'm wrong and you know firsthand.)

The UK economy had consistent unemployment rates above 7.0% from 2009 to 2013 during the GFC. The current pandemic should be worse (in the short run).  So 88% for more than 7.0%. The rest are in the field to cover any measurement issues (lags).

Labour market reform in the UK over the past few years has driven a growth in precarious forms of employment, including part-time work and zero-hour contracts, giving a low employment rate unrepresentative of the economy. These jobs will likely be lost during the pandemic.

https://www.cityam.com/ons-job-vacancies-sank-as-uk-entered-coronavirus-lockdown/
March was not that bad about 4% but it is expected to rocket to 9-10% after lockdown.

UPD: 4 % Unemployment corresponds to 1.34 Mio people meaning that every 1 % is ca. 350 K
The new payments of Universal Credit reached ca. 700K by the 5th of May 
https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/universal-credit-declarations-claims-and-advances-management-information
This brings confidently the unemployment to 2 Mio already. The question whether it will feed into official statistic but there is a good chance that the unemployment rate will get into 6 - 7 % range. Looking at previous numbers for 2008-2009 recession even at the steepest part of the curve the monthly growth was 0.5%. Even under assumption of absolutely unprecedented severity of the current crisis there is fairly low chance that the curve will go so steep that the unemployment rate will shoot 3 % in over 3 months. It takes quite a bit of effort to apply for benefits and lag in putting all the registrations especially with government offices working at half capacity. However, the online system may speed up the whole process and the 6 higher rate would be achieved. Still while 7% unemployment rate will be certainly achieved at some point in future it is unlikely it will be reached in March - May 2020 statistical data.

Highest historical monthly increase was 0.328 percentage points between Feb and Mar 2009 period. Assuming average monthly increase since Feb 2020 4% unemployment rate is 0.328, employment rate for Mar-May 2020 would be 4.945%. Fair to assume average will be at least that high given immediacy of shock. Average monthly increases would have to rise to about a 0.75 a month, twice the historical high for a single month and sustained for three months to get to bin 4 of 6-7%.  Average monthly increase would have to rise to about 1 percentage point a month, ~3 times the historical high for a single month and sustained for three months to get to bin 4 of >7%. Certainly possible, but thinking the crowd may be overestimating the speed of reporting; the forecasts of top forecasters on this question suggest this may be wise. Will re-evaluate after May's report for Jan-Mar.

Recent releases from BA say they are considering makgin 12,000 staff reduntant - approx 1/4 of their workforce. This suggest my assumption that these industries will be protected is not currently being assumed by the industry themselves and they're more likely to have a better idea than I do. So I am raising the probability of the result landing in the 5-6 marginally but the probability of being in the 6-7 more significantly.
Revising downwards due to uncertainty around how the statistics will be gathered / where furloughed employees will be counted.

The UK unemployment rate in the 3 months leading up to February 2020 was already estimated at a record high. The rate was 4% in the 3 months to Feb 2020. Given the COVID-19 impact on employment, despite the furlough scheme, there are still significant numbers who have lost employment due to companies insolvency and those working in sectors where wages are not a significant portion of the company costs. If those furloughed were considered unemployed then the number would almost certainly be more than 7.0%. https://www.ons.gov.uk/employmentandlabourmarket/peoplenotinwork/unemployment
https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/apr/21/uk-unemployment-coronavirus-ons-figures-jobs
https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/apr/21/uk-furlough-scheme-unemployment-rise-coronavirus

In normal times we see little seasonal variation in unemployment rates between Nov to Jan and Jan to March. So can assume a base rate of around 4%. Unemployed people are defined as those aged 16 or over who are without work, available to start work in the next two weeks and who have either: a) been actively seeking work in the past four weeks, or. b) are waiting to start a new job they have already obtained. The UK has put in place significant support measures for companies, allowing them to furlough staff and the gov will pay up to 80% of their wages. Anybody in this situation will not count as unemployed in the stats as they are not actively seeking alternative work. The same applies for the self-employed.  We can assume that faced with difficult economic prospects most firms and self-employed will simply seek to temporarily cease all or parts of operations, allowing employees to access these funds and avoid unemployment. Where we will see increased unemployment is where firms actually become insolvent. I've been unable to find any evidence of increasing insolvencies. Firms most susceptible to this will be ones where a significant proportion of expenses aren't wages. So will fall hardest on the non-service sector. But these sectors are ones the government is prioritising for support - construction, food supply, transport. So we can assume the government will prop up a significant proportion.  So we conclude that unemployment as defined and measured by ONS won't see a huge change. However, there are currently 1.34 million unemployed and 32.99m employed. It would only take 1% of those employed to lose their jobs to lead to a 1ppt rise in the unemployment rate.  We therefore conclude there is virtually no possiblity of unemployment being below 4% the current rate and only a slightly higher probability of it being above 7%.  The most likely outcome seems to be it woudl be within 4% and 6%. We estimate it is twice as likely it is higher than 5%.
Backing down with the probabilities here. The statistics may need time to catch up to reality.
As lockdown is eased people will want to ‘stay on furlough’ and be fired for not returning to work.
Here is the thing. Furloughs might muck-up the rate. https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/apr/21/uk-furlough-scheme-unemployment-rise-coronavirus

with the Chancellor talking about another 2m unemployed currently that boosts the current rate to over 8%. expectations are that business number will return to nearer normal pre lock down numbers but i suspect the unemployment rate will lag as the weak businesses that have goe bust wont come back. Either way by end May it likely that with a lockdown gradual release early May, numbers will still be significant.

Forecast out today, 14 April, by the UK's Office for Budget Responsibility: "...a steep rise in the unemployment rate to 10 per cent in the second quarter, equivalent to an increase in unemployment of 2.1 million (to a total of 3.4 million). As with GDP, the rise in unemployment is likely to be very fast, as the sharp rise in new claims for UC already attests." https://obr.uk/coronavirus-reference-scenario/
Shifting to higher bins, while I still don't appreciate how UE is counted or who is counted, I'll go higher.

Fiddling with the numbers to push on the higher end.
It all depends on how the numbers are calculated and who qualifies as unemployed. Each country is different.
See Ewell Gregoor’s comments. Crucila information as to what is counted.

See previous post on the criteria for unemployment and how this relates to Covid.  Bloomberg today predicted a peak as high as 6%, others see it as high as 8.5%. As far as im aware, Furlough is in place as long as June, therefore Furlough should cover this question period. If there is a rise in unemployment, it shall be after Furlough ends in June.

There might even be a much higher peak, but on average coming from 3.9 with employee-friendly laws and billions from the state to save jobs it´s down to when and how people can get to work again. Denmark and Austria are taking first steps already, allowing small shops and some schools to open. Germany plans first steps starting 20 April. The UK might be 2-3 weeks behind that, but with a chance for improvement in the near future, not everone will be fired.
Writing in the Guardian, the economist said UK unemployment could rapidly rise to more than 6 million people, around 21% of the entire workforce,

While the eventual unemployment rate is likely to exceed 7%, in 2008 recession it took a year to reach that level from an even higher starting point. In 3 months time will the rate grow several times faster than in 2008? The US experience would say yes. But the UK has different metrics. I'll mimic @Ewell_Gregoor & @pstamp and their approach.

Had a reply from the OFNS Labour Market team. The reply is below: Hi Ewell

Our employment and unemployment statistics are compiled using the Labour Force Survey, a household survey.
You may find the following link useful https://www.ons.gov.uk/employmentandlabourmarket/peopleinwork/employmentandemployeetypes/methodologies/aguidetolabourmarketstatistics

Q: will people on PAYE who are currently on furlough count towards government 
unemployment stats?
A)This depends on how people answer the survey, but we believe people will say that they haven’t worked in the reference week but away from a job that they are expecting to return to…..and will be classified as employed Q) will self employed people who are claiming furlough count towards 
unemployment stats. 
A)As above D) can a self employed person count towards unemployed stats. 
Q) No not if work has been done in reference week, or person away from a business that they expected to return to Q) is there any changes in the criteria for unemployment 
A)The definition of unemployment is people without a job who have been actively seeking work within the last four weeks and are available to start work within the next two weeks.  The large majority of Furloughed staff, both PAYE and Self employed will not count towards unemployment stats. Those self employed with a UTR number will also not count, as there claim would be based on working on the reference date which I believe to be February 28th.  This question is not a given, with Furlough in place till June. 
I am reducing my forecast based on this reply. See previous post for predictions based on regression to the mean, think it will be really close between the highest 2 categories.

Will furloughed staff go into unemployment stats? That’s a very important factor for this question, I wouldn’t expect they would as they are employed by the state. I have posted before about scepticism about unemployment figures, through looking at the definition on the U.K. stats website, I don’t think universal credit applicants who are self employed will count towards the figure. As they are ‘self’ employed but getting paid by the state.  I have emailed the  OFNS these questions to ask. 
Will let you know the response. Until then I’m reserving going too high on the higher amount

current rate of 3.7% which makes 1.34m-economically active of 36m . Reported that further 1m people applied for ESA so can be deemed as unemployed. If this number is added then makes unemployment rate of circa 6%. However there is an increase of emplyment in key areas. Also not predicting furloughed staff or business on temporary cessation would include in the unemployment numbers hence predicting on 20% of over 7%.

It won´t be as bad as feared with all those government billions being spent. And a possible peak does not mean, the whole quarter is that bad. Thanks to @CP1988 and @lapp0 for sharing the results of their research. I´m going down with my numbers a little because of them.

The surge in new claims wipe out 77% of the 1.23 million new jobs created between the referendum of June 2016 and January 2020 while implying a severe increase in unemployment that's likely to lift the jobless rate by 2.7 percentage points to 6.6% for the three months to the end of March.

First of all it is important to note that the widely reported  surge in Universal Credit claims [1] does not necessarily correlate exactly with unemployment as ONS use a Labour Force survey as a measurement and the claimant count is usually *below* the unemployment rate [2]. The 950K surge implies at least an unemployment rate of approx 6.3%, however this is likely to be underestimating the actual unemployment rate - though not necessarily by much (the difference between claimant count and unemployment was about 0.1% in the last dataset). I am also sceptical of the forecasts made by financial institutions who seemed to underestimate the size of the crisis incoming judging by their economic forecasts from March 2020 [3]. I am aware this data will have been compiled quite a bit earlier than publication date but it should have been clear by the start of March the scale of the crisis. I expect current lockdown will continue for the duration of this question and given the economic package announced I don't expect another surge like we've seen with the initial spike. I think the crowd is underestimating the chance of a 6-7% unemployment rate as data suggests that is the current level however I accept there is the capacity for this figure to grow - even if not as much as the initial spike and this would take it over to the 7% figure. Given the post GFE baserate of unemployment being over 7% in the UK is quite high and adjusting for this extraordinary scenario I make 7% or over the most likely outcome but between 6-7% also being feasible.  [1] https://www.theguardian.com/society/2020/apr/01/950000-apply-for-universal-credit-in-two-weeks-of-uk-lockdown  [2] https://www.ons.gov.uk/employmentandlabourmarket/peopleinwork/employmentandemployeetypes/methodologies/aguidetolabourmarketstatistics#unemployment [3] https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/data-forecasts

Having read a article in the business section of the Sunday times predicting higher than I expected levels of unemployment I'm tweaking my forecast , however , I do still feel that with the government supporting jobs and the increased staffing need in the food supply , NHS and other services jobs could be relocated.

After reading the Economist's article on unintended consequences of the job retention scheme I'm having doubts of how big of an effect it will have on unemployment. Increasing the probability of more than 7% unemployment rate.  HT: @akmenim https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1004705
https://www.economist.com/britain/2020/03/26/the-jobs-retention-schemes-unintended-consequences
US article forecasts unemployment in US may reach 32%

The outlook is relatively grim for the UK’s economy as the virus continues to spread.  Several firms estimate a 6% unemployment rate for the next period, but there is a high chance this could be a low-ball.  
Sunak’s proposal for furloughing workers, whose salaries can be paid at 80% on the government dime, will no doubt be helpful, but much of the damage has been done already, in a slow-burn fashion that may not yet be readily apparent.  
Johnson’s delay in taking drastic public health measures has given the virus more time to spread, and companies, not just politicians, have historically underestimated the economic damage that the virus can cause.  
The exchequer’s plan is also not without issues: The Economist noted that the furloughed workers, unable to work under the current proposal, would deflate labor supply towards those industries that are seeing an increase in demand; this in turn would prevent the labor market from operating at maximum efficiency (attached link). https://www.economist.com/britain/2020/03/26/the-jobs-retention-schemes-unintended-consequences

The times are claiming it will be over 8%.

Starting this with the outside view: Since 2010 the highest rate of unemployment was 8% and the lowest 3.8%. Giving a medium average of 5.9%. 
January unemployment was at 3.9%. So regression to the mean says the next month without Covid a purely outside perspective would indicate a rate of 4.9%. given the circumstances, that pretty much rules out anything sub 5% Other Factors to consider - 
How will they determine unemployment,
OFNS "Unemployment measures people without a job who have been actively seeking work within the last four weeks and are available to start work within the next two weeks. The unemployment rate is not the proportion of the total population who are unemployed. It is the proportion of the economically active population (those in work plus those seeking and available to work) who are unemployed" I doubt this criteria will meet those self employed workers in the UK who make up 5 million of the workforce, as they will still be classed as self employed.  A yougov poll recently claimed that 1/20 workers has lost their jobs already. 
Assume that some are students who wont impact these figures, 5 million self employed who wont impact the figures, those over the retirement age who wont impact the figures. I would assume that a fairer reflection would be 1 in 50 will count towards these stats. 2%.  I have seen stats for Norway indicating 10% unemployment. however the British bailout seems to protect workers paying up to 80% of their wages. The British Chancellor has been praised by socialist Bernie Sanders, such are the protections offered.  I will therefore add 4.9% and 2% to get my predicted figure of 6.9% unemployment rate. The unemployment rate that was recorded by the UK Office of National Statistics for the period of November-January was 3.9%. As reported by the Financial Times, the UK has already seen a loss of 200,000 jobs in the leisure and hospitality sectors as a direct result of COVID-19. The Financial Times predicts that by the end of the second quarter, that number will rise to approximately 700,000 across all industries. As of March 26, around 9,500 residents have tested positive for the disease and the government has continued to restrict gatherings and push social distancing and self-quarantine. Due to this, the unemployment rate will be likely to double by the end of the March-May period.

Even at this point close to 477k have filed for unemployment and in my base case I factor UK going the same way as France and Spain as avg age is still 40.So unemployment still rising from current levels. Will wait to see the effectiveness of the virus aid disbursement before revising forecasts

I think this is harder to call than it looks, because the UK has created a new class of 'Furloughed Worker' where they aren't working but the government is paying their salary. That is likely to keep a lot of people off the unemployment numbers for at least the relevant time period. I'm also struck by how slowly unemployment rose in previous recessions, taking many quarters to rise by even 1%. Clearly the coronavirus impact will be faster, but I do wonder if the impact won't be that big that quickly. It's hard to get data beyond anecdote, but it seems many companies are retaining people for now at least. I wonder if the rise won't be 1-2% only. On the other hand, the Mirror says there has been almost 500k applications for Universal Credit in the last 9 days; equivilant to 1.5% growth already. I think a flatish curve of predictions is sensible here, with a largish tail since an extremely high number is clearly possible.
https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/breaking-coronavirus-sees-500000-universal-21750211 - keeping forecat the same, just adding data

The c.200k jobs gone in leisure takes UE to roughly 4.5% & roughly doubling that across other industries would take it to c.5%, significantly reducing probability of first two options.  However, the government support is unprecedented:  On the business side, the gov's 80% of salary offer along with a multitude of low-to-no interest bridge financing options should help stem tide. These schemes, along with the particularly human (rather than predominantly economic) side of this crisis, should give business leaders pause for thought: they have a v low-cost option to furlough their workforce and delay the decision, as well as avoid severe hardship for their employees. 
In addition, there is the option for those who were let go prior to the gov's announcement to appeal to their old employers to be furloughed retrospectively.  On the labour side, mortgage payment holiday increases employee appetite to take salary reductions for a period.  The major concern around self-employed population should also be addressed through further a further government support package in next few days (latest by Friday) and is likely to be similar in nature to 80% salary support.

Unemployment was around 7-8% for most of the duration of the 2008 recession afaik, and I strongly expect this employment shock to be at least as sharp given that we essentially have a government-mandated shutdown of all economic activity. Of course the Treasury's relief package will aim to limit the number of layoffs, but it seems very likely there will be many, especially among the self-employed.
